column2: CHAPTER VII.

column2: JEM WILSON'S REPULSE.
column3: JEM WILSON'S REPULSE.

column2: How infinite the wealth of love and hope Garnered in these same tiny treasure-houses! And oh! what bankrupts in the world we feel, When Death, like some remorseless creditor, Seizes on all we fondly thought our own!
column3: How infinite the wealth of love and hope Garnered in these same tiny treasure houses! And oh! what bankrupts in the world we feel, When Death, like some remorseless creditor, Seizes on all we fondly thought our own!

column2: THE TWINS.
column3: THE TWINS.

column2: The ghoul-like fever was not to be braved with impunity, and baulked of its prey.
column3: The ghoul like fever was not to be braved with impunity, and baulked of its prey.

column2: The widow had reclaimed her children; her neighbours, in the good Samaritan sense of the word, had paid her little arrears of rent, and made her a few shillings beforehand with the world. She determined to flit from that cellar to another less full of painful associations, less haunted by mournful memories.
column3: The widow had reclaimed her children; her neighbours, in the good Samaritan sense of the word, had paid her little arrears of rent, and made her a few shillings beforehand with the world. She determined to flit from that cellar to another less full of painful associations, less haunted by mournful memories.

column2: The board, not so formidable as she had imagined, had inquired into her case; and, instead of sending her to Stoke Claypole, her husband's Buckinghamshire parish, as she had dreaded, had agreed to pay her rent.
column3: The board, not so formidable as she had imagined, had inquired into her case; and, instead of sending her to Stoke Claypole, her husband's Buckinghamshire parish, as she had dreaded, had agreed to pay her rent.

column2: So food for four mouths was all she was now required to find; only for three she would have said; for herself and the unweaned child were but reckoned as one in her calculation.
column3: So food for four mouths was all she was now required to find; only for three she would have said; for herself and the unweaned child were but reckoned as one in her calculation.

column2: She had a strong heart, now her bodily strength had been recruited by a week or two of food, and she would not despair.
column3: She had a strong heart, now her bodily strength had been recruited by a week or two of food, and she would not despair.

column2: So she took in some little children to nurse, who brought their daily food with them, which she cooked for them, without wronging their helplessness of a crumb; and when she had restored them to their mothers at night, she set to work at plain sewing, "seam, and gusset, and band," and sat thinking how she might best cheat the factory inspector, and persuade him that her strong, big, hungry Ben was above thirteen.
column3: So she took in some little children to nurse, who brought their daily food with them, which she cooked for them, without wronging their helplessness of a crumb; and when she had restored them to their mothers at night, she set to work at plain sewing, "seam, and gusset, and band," and sat thinking how she might best cheat the factory inspector, and persuade him that her strong, big, hungry Ben was above thirteen.

column2: Her plan of living was so far arranged, when she heard, with keen sorrow, that Wilson's twin lads were ill of the fever.
column3: Her plan of living was so far arranged, when she heard, with keen sorrow, that Wilson's twin lads were ill of the fever.

column2: They had never been strong.
column3: They had never been strong.

column2: They were like many a pair of twins, and seemed to have but one life divided between them.
column3: They were like many a pair of twins, and seemed to have but one life divided between them.

column2: One life, one strength, and in this instance, I might almost say, one brain; for they were helpless, gentle, silly children, but not the less dear to their parents and to their strong, active, manly, elder brother. They were late on their feet, late in talking, late every way; had to be nursed and cared for when other lads of their age were tumbling about in the street, and losing themselves, and being taken to the police-office miles away from home.
column3: One life, one strength, and in this instance, I might almost say, one brain; for they were helpless, gentle, silly children, but not the less dear to their parents and to their strong, active, manly, elder brother. They were late on their feet, late in talking, late every way; had to be nursed and cared for when other lads of their age were tumbling about in the street, and losing themselves, and being taken to the police office miles away from home.

column2: Still want had never yet come in at the door to make love for these innocents fly out at the window.
column3: Still want had never yet come in at the door to make love for these innocents fly out at the window.

column2: Nor was this the case even now, when Jem Wilson's earnings, and his mother's occasional charrings were barely sufficient to give all the family their fill of food.
column3: Nor was this the case even now, when Jem Wilson's earnings, and his mother's occasional charrings were barely sufficient to give all the family their fill of food.

column2: But when the twins, after ailing many days, and caring little for their meat, fell sick on the same afternoon, with the same heavy stupor of suffering, the three hearts that loved them so, each felt, though none acknowledged to the other, that they had little chance for life.
column3: But when the twins, after ailing many days, and caring little for their meat, fell sick on the same afternoon, with the same heavy stupor of suffering, the three hearts that loved them so, each felt, though none acknowledged to the other, that they had little chance for life.

column2: It was nearly a week before the tale of their illness spread as far as the court where the Wilsons had once dwelt, and the Bartons yet lived.
column3: It was nearly a week before the tale of their illness spread as far as the court where the Wilsons had once dwelt, and the Bartons yet lived.

column2: Alice had heard of the illness of her little nephews several days before, and had locked her cellar door, and gone off straight to her brother's house, in Ancoats; but she was often absent for days, sent for, as her neighbours knew, to help in some sudden emergency of illness or distress, so that occasioned no surprise.
column3: Alice had heard of the illness of her little nephews several days before, and had locked her cellar door, and gone off straight to her brother's house, in Ancoats; but she was often absent for days, sent for, as her neighbours knew, to help in some sudden emergency of illness or distress, so that occasioned no surprise.

column2: Margaret met Jem Wilson several days after his brothers were seriously ill, and heard from him the state of things at his home. She told Mary of it as she entered the court late that evening; and Mary listened with saddened heart to the strange contrast which such woeful tidings presented to the gay and loving words she had been hearing on her walk home.
column3: Margaret met Jem Wilson several days after his brothers were seriously ill, and heard from him the state of things at his home. She told Mary of it as she entered the court late that evening; and Mary listened with saddened heart to the strange contrast which such woeful tidings presented to the gay and loving words she had been hearing on her walk home.

column2: She blamed herself for being so much taken up with visions of the golden future, that she had lately gone but seldom on Sunday afternoons, or other leisure time, to see Mrs. Wilson, her mother's friend; and with hasty purpose of amendment she only stayed to leave a message for her father with the next-door neighbour, and then went off at a brisk pace on her way to the house of mourning.
column3: She blamed herself for being so much taken up with visions of the golden future, that she had lately gone but seldom on Sunday afternoons, or other leisure time, to see mrs Wilson, her mother's friend; and with hasty purpose of amendment she only stayed to leave a message for her father with the next door neighbour, and then went off at a brisk pace on her way to the house of mourning.

column2: She stopped with her hand on the latch of the Wilsons' door, to still her beating heart, and listened to the hushed quiet within. She opened the door softly: there sat Mrs. Wilson in the old rocking-chair, with one sick, death-like boy lying on her knee, crying without let or pause, but softly, gently, as fearing to disturb the troubled, gasping child; while behind her, old Alice let her fast-dropping tears fall down on the dead body of the other twin, which she was laying out on a board, placed on a sort of sofa-settee in a corner of the room.
column3: She stopped with her hand on the latch of the Wilsons' door, to still her beating heart, and listened to the hushed quiet within. She opened the door softly: there sat mrs Wilson in the old rocking chair, with one sick, death like boy lying on her knee, crying without let or pause, but softly, gently, as fearing to disturb the troubled, gasping child; while behind her, old Alice let her fast dropping tears fall down on the dead body of the other twin, which she was laying out on a board, placed on a sort of sofa settee in a corner of the room.

column2: Over the child, which yet breathed, the father bent, watching anxiously for some ground of hope, where hope there was none.
column3: Over the child, which yet breathed, the father bent, watching anxiously for some ground of hope, where hope there was none.

column2: Mary stepped slowly and lightly across to Alice.
column3: Mary stepped slowly and lightly across to Alice.

column2: Ay, poor lad!	Ay, poor lad!

column2: God has taken him early, Mary."
column3: God has taken him early, Mary."

column2: Mary could not speak; she did not know what to say; it was so much worse than she expected.
column3: Mary could not speak; she did not know what to say; it was so much worse than she expected.

column2: At last she ventured to whisper,
column3: At last she ventured to whisper,

column2: Is there any chance for the other one, think you?
column3: Is there any chance for the other one, think you?

column2: Alice shook her head, and told with a look that she believed there was none.
column3: Alice shook her head, and told with a look that she believed there was none.

column2: She next endeavoured to lift the little body, and carry it to its old accustomed bed in its parents' room.
column3: She next endeavoured to lift the little body, and carry it to its old accustomed bed in its parents' room.

column2: But earnest as the father was in watching the yet-living, he had eyes and ears for all that concerned the dead, and sprang gently up, and took his dead son on his hard couch in his arms with tender strength, and carried him upstairs as if afraid of wakening him.
column3: But earnest as the father was in watching the yet living, he had eyes and ears for all that concerned the dead, and sprang gently up, and took his dead son on his hard couch in his arms with tender strength, and carried him upstairs as if afraid of wakening him.

column2: The other child gasped longer, louder, with more of effort.
column3: The other child gasped longer, louder, with more of effort.

column2: We mun get him away from his mother.	We mun get him away from his mother.

column2: He cannot die while she's wishing him."
column3: He cannot die while she's wishing him."

column2: Wishing him? said Mary, in a tone of inquiry.
column3: Wishing him? said Mary, in a tone of inquiry.

column2: Ay; donno ye know what wishing means?	Ay; donno ye know what wishing means?
column3: false

column2: There's none can die in the arms of those who are wishing them sore to stay on earth.
column3: There's none can die in the arms of those who are wishing them sore to stay on earth.

column2: The soul o' them as holds them won't let the dying soul go free; so it has a hard struggle for the quiet of death.
column3: The soul o' them as holds them won't let the dying soul go free; so it has a hard struggle for the quiet of death.

column2: We mun get him away fra' his mother, or he'll have a hard death, poor lile [20] fellow."
column3: We mun get him away fra' his mother, or he'll have a hard death, poor lile [twenty] fellow."

column2: [Footnote 20: "Lile," a north-country word for "little." "Wit _leil_ labour to live."--_Piers Ploughman._]
column3: [Footnote twenty: "Lile," a north country word for "little." "Wit underscore leil underscore labour to live."--underscore Piers Ploughman.underscore]

column2: So without circumlocution she went and offered to take the sinking child.
column3: So without circumlocution she went and offered to take the sinking child.

column2: But the mother would not let him go, and looking in Alice's face with brimming and imploring eyes, declared in earnest whispers, that she was not wishing him, that she would fain have him released from his suffering.
column3: But the mother would not let him go, and looking in Alice's face with brimming and imploring eyes, declared in earnest whispers, that she was not wishing him, that she would fain have him released from his suffering.

column2: Alice and Mary stood by with eyes fixed on the poor child, whose struggles seemed to increase, till at last his mother said with a choking voice,
column3: Alice and Mary stood by with eyes fixed on the poor child, whose struggles seemed to increase, till at last his mother said with a choking voice,

column2: May happen [21] yo'd better take him, Alice; I believe my heart's wishing him a' this while, for I cannot, no, I cannot bring mysel to let my two childer go in one day; I cannot help longing to keep him, and yet he sha'not suffer longer for me.
column3: May happen [twenty one] yo'd better take him, Alice; I believe my heart's wishing him a' this while, for I cannot, no, I cannot bring mysel to let my two childer go in one day; I cannot help longing to keep him, and yet he sha'not suffer longer for me.

column2: [Footnote 21: "May happen," perhaps.]
column3: [Footnote twenty one: "May happen," perhaps.]

column2: She bent down, and fondly, oh! with what passionate fondness, kissed her child, and then gave him up to Alice, who took him with tender care.
column3: She bent down, and fondly, oh! with what passionate fondness, kissed her child, and then gave him up to Alice, who took him with tender care.

column2: Nature's struggles were soon exhausted, and he breathed his little life away in peace.
column3: Nature's struggles were soon exhausted, and he breathed his little life away in peace.

column2: Then the mother lifted up her voice and wept.
column3: Then the mother lifted up her voice and wept.

column2: Her cries brought her husband down to try with his aching heart to comfort hers.
column3: Her cries brought her husband down to try with his aching heart to comfort hers.

column2: Again Alice laid out the dead, Mary helping with reverent fear.
column3: Again Alice laid out the dead, Mary helping with reverent fear.

column2: The father and mother carried him up-stairs to the bed, where his little brother lay in calm repose.
column3: The father and mother carried him up stairs to the bed, where his little brother lay in calm repose.

column2: Mary and Alice drew near the fire, and stood in quiet sorrow for some time.
column3: Mary and Alice drew near the fire, and stood in quiet sorrow for some time.

column2: Then Alice broke the silence by saying,
column3: Then Alice broke the silence by saying,

column2: It will be bad news for Jem, poor fellow, when he comes home.
column3: It will be bad news for Jem, poor fellow, when he comes home.

column2: Where is he? asked Mary.
column3: Where is he? asked Mary.

column2: Working over-hours at th' shop.	Working over hours at t h' shop.

column2: They'n getten a large order fra' forrin parts; and yo' know, Jem mun work, though his heart's well-nigh breaking for these poor laddies."
column3: They'n getten a large order fra' forrin parts; and yo' know, Jem mun work, though his heart's well nigh breaking for these poor laddies."

column2: Again they were silent in thought, and again Alice spoke first.
column3: Again they were silent in thought, and again Alice spoke first.

column2: I sometimes think the Lord is against planning.	I sometimes think the Lord is against planning.
column3: false

column2: Whene'er I plan over-much, He is sure to send and mar all my plans, as if He would ha' me put the future into His hands.
column3: Whene'er I plan over much, He is sure to send and mar all my plans, as if He would ha' me put the future into His hands.

column2: Afore Christmas-time I was as full as full could be, of going home for good and all; yo' han heard how I've wished it this terrible long time.
column3: Afore Christmas time I was as full as full could be, of going home for good and all; yo' han heard how I've wished it this terrible long time.

column2: And a young lass from behind Burton came into place in Manchester last Martinmas; so after awhile, she had a Sunday out, and she comes to me, and tells me some cousins o' mine bid her find me out, and say how glad they should be to ha' me to bide wi' 'em, and look after th' childer, for they'n getten a big farm, and she's a deal to do among th' cows.
column3: And a young lass from behind Burton came into place in Manchester last Martinmas; so after awhile, she had a Sunday out, and she comes to me, and tells me some cousins o' mine bid her find me out, and say how glad they should be to ha' me to bide wi' 'em, and look after thanksgiving' childer, for they'n getten a big farm, and she's a deal to do among t h' cows.

column2: So many a winter's night did I lie awake and think, that please God, come summer, I'd bid George and his wife good bye, and go home at last. Little did I think how God Almighty would baulk me, for not leaving my days in His hands, who had led me through the wilderness hitherto. Here's George out o' work, and more cast down than ever I seed him; wanting every chip o' comfort he can get, e'en afore this last heavy stroke; and now I'm thinking the Lord's finger points very clear to my fit abiding place; and I'm sure if George and Jane can say 'His will be done,' it's no more than what I'm beholden to do."
column3: So many a winter's night did I lie awake and think, that please God, come summer, I'd bid George and his wife good bye, and go home at last. Little did I think how God Almighty would baulk me, for not leaving my days in His hands, who had led me through the wilderness hitherto. Here's George out o' work, and more cast down than ever I seed him; wanting every chip o' comfort he can get, e'en afore this last heavy stroke; and now I'm thinking the Lord's finger points very clear to my fit abiding place; and I'm sure if George and Jane can say 'His will be done,' it's no more than what I'm beholden to do."

column2: So saying, she fell to tidying the room, removing as much as she could every vestige of sickness; making up the fire, and setting on the kettle for a cup of tea for her sister-in-law, whose low moans and sobs were occasionally heard in the room below.
column3: So saying, she fell to tidying the room, removing as much as she could every vestige of sickness; making up the fire, and setting on the kettle for a cup of tea for her sister in law, whose low moans and sobs were occasionally heard in the room below.

column3: Mary helped her in all these little offices.

column3: They were busy in this way when the door was softly opened, and Jem came in, all grimed and dirty from his night work, his soiled apron wrapped round his middle, in guise and apparel in which he would have been sorry at another time to have been seen by Mary.

column2: But just now he hardly saw her; he went straight up to Alice, and asked how the little chaps were.
column3: But just now he hardly saw her; he went straight up to Alice, and asked how the little chaps were.

column2: They had been a shade better at dinner-time, and he had been working away through the long afternoon, and far into the night, in the belief that they had taken the turn.
column3: They had been a shade better at dinner time, and he had been working away through the long afternoon, and far into the night, in the belief that they had taken the turn.

column3: He had stolen out during the half hour allowed at the works for tea, to buy them an orange or two, which now puffed out his jacket pocket.

column3: Dead!

column3: Jem went to the cupboard, and quietly extricated from his pocket the oranges he had bought.

column2: But he stayed long there, and at last his sturdy frame shook with his strong agony.
column3: But he stayed long there, and at last his sturdy frame shook with his strong agony.

column2: The two women were frightened, as women always are, on witnessing a man's overpowering grief.
column3: The two women were frightened, as women always are, on witnessing a man's overpowering grief.

column2: They cried afresh in company.
column3: They cried afresh in company.

column2: Mary's heart melted within her as she witnessed Jem's sorrow, and she stepped gently up to the corner where he stood, with his back turned to them, and putting her hand softly on his arm, said,
column3: Mary's heart melted within her as she witnessed Jem's sorrow, and she stepped gently up to the corner where he stood, with his back turned to them, and putting her hand softly on his arm, said,

column2: Oh, Jem, don't give way so; I cannot bear to see you.
column3: Oh, Jem, don't give way so; I cannot bear to see you.

column2: Jem felt a strange leap of joy in his heart, and knew the power she had of comforting him.
column3: Jem felt a strange leap of joy in his heart, and knew the power she had of comforting him.

column2: He did not speak, as though fearing to destroy by sound or motion the happiness of that moment, when her soft hand's touch thrilled through his frame, and her silvery voice was whispering tenderness in his ear.
column3: He did not speak, as though fearing to destroy by sound or motion the happiness of that moment, when her soft hand's touch thrilled through his frame, and her silvery voice was whispering tenderness in his ear.

column2: Yes! it might be very wrong; he could almost hate himself for it; with death and woe so surrounding him, it yet was happiness, was bliss, to be so spoken to by Mary.
column3: Yes! it might be very wrong; he could almost hate himself for it; with death and woe so surrounding him, it yet was happiness, was bliss, to be so spoken to by Mary.

column2: Don't, Jem, please don't, whispered she again, believing that his silence was only another form of grief.
column3: Don't, Jem, please don't, whispered she again, believing that his silence was only another form of grief.

column2: He could not contain himself.
column3: He could not contain himself.

column2: He took her hand in his firm yet trembling grasp, and said, in tones that instantly produced a revulsion in her mood,
column3: He took her hand in his firm yet trembling grasp, and said, in tones that instantly produced a revulsion in her mood,

column2: Mary, I almost loathe myself when I feel I would not give up this minute, when my brothers lie dead, and father and mother are in such trouble, for all my life that's past and gone.	Mary, I almost loathe myself when I feel I would not give up this minute, when my brothers lie dead, and father and mother are in such trouble, for all my life that's past and gone.

column2: And, Mary (as she tried to release her hand), you know what makes me feel so blessed."
column3: And, Mary (as she tried to release her hand), you know what makes me feel so blessed."

column2: She did know--he was right there.
column3: She did know-he was right there.

column2: But as he turned to catch a look at her sweet face, he saw that it expressed unfeigned distress, almost amounting to vexation; a dread of him, that he thought was almost repugnance.
column3: But as he turned to catch a look at her sweet face, he saw that it expressed unfeigned distress, almost amounting to vexation; a dread of him, that he thought was almost repugnance.

column2: He let her hand go, and she quickly went away to Alice's side.
column3: He let her hand go, and she quickly went away to Alice's side.

column2: Fool that I was--nay, wretch that I was--to let myself take this time of trouble to tell her how I loved her; no wonder that she turns away from such a selfish beast.
column3: Fool that I was-nay, wretch that I was-to let myself take this time of trouble to tell her how I loved her; no wonder that she turns away from such a selfish beast.

column2: Partly to relieve her from his presence, and partly from natural desire, and partly, perhaps, from a penitent wish to share to the utmost his parents' sorrow, he soon went up-stairs to the chamber of death.
column3: Partly to relieve her from his presence, and partly from natural desire, and partly, perhaps, from a penitent wish to share to the utmost his parents' sorrow, he soon went up stairs to the chamber of death.

column2: Mary mechanically helped Alice in all the duties she performed through the remainder of that long night, but she did not see Jem again.
column3: Mary mechanically helped Alice in all the duties she performed through the remainder of that long night, but she did not see Jem again.

column2: He remained up-stairs until after the early dawn showed Mary that she need have no fear of going home through the deserted and quiet streets, to try and get a little sleep before work hour.
column3: He remained up stairs until after the early dawn showed Mary that she need have no fear of going home through the deserted and quiet streets, to try and get a little sleep before work hour.

column2: So leaving kind messages to George and Jane Wilson, and hesitating whether she might dare to send a few kind words to Jem, and deciding that she had better not, she stepped out into the bright morning light, so fresh a contrast to the darkened room where death had been.
column3: So leaving kind messages to George and Jane Wilson, and hesitating whether she might dare to send a few kind words to Jem, and deciding that she had better not, she stepped out into the bright morning light, so fresh a contrast to the darkened room where death had been.

column2: They had Another morn than ours.
column3: They had Another morn than ours.

column2: Mary lay down on her bed in her clothes; and whether it was this, or the broad daylight that poured in through the sky-window, or whether it was over-excitement, it was long before she could catch a wink of sleep.
column3: Mary lay down on her bed in her clothes; and whether it was this, or the broad daylight that poured in through the sky window, or whether it was over excitement, it was long before she could catch a wink of sleep.

column2: Her thoughts ran on Jem's manner and words; not but what she had known the tale they told for many a day; but still she wished he had not put it so plainly.
column3: Her thoughts ran on Jem's manner and words; not but what she had known the tale they told for many a day; but still she wished he had not put it so plainly.

column2: Oh dear, said she to herself, "I wish he would not mistake me so; I never dare to speak a common word o' kindness, but his eye brightens and his cheek flushes.
column3: Oh dear, said she to herself, "I wish he would not mistake me so; I never dare to speak a common word o' kindness, but his eye brightens and his cheek flushes.

column2: It's very hard on me; for father and George Wilson are old friends; and Jem and I ha' known each other since we were quite children.
column3: It's very hard on me; for father and George Wilson are old friends; and Jem and I ha' known each other since we were quite children.

column2: I cannot think what possesses me, that I must always be wanting to comfort him when he's downcast, and that I must go meddling wi' him to-night, when sure enough it was his aunt's place to speak to him.
column3: I cannot think what possesses me, that I must always be wanting to comfort him when he's downcast, and that I must go meddling wi' him to night, when sure enough it was his aunt's place to speak to him.

column2: I don't care for him, and yet, unless I'm always watching myself, I'm speaking to him in a loving voice.
column3: I don't care for him, and yet, unless I'm always watching myself, I'm speaking to him in a loving voice.

column2: I think I cannot go right, for I either check myself till I'm downright cross to him, or else I speak just natural, and that's too kind and tender by half.
column3: I think I cannot go right, for I either check myself till I'm downright cross to him, or else I speak just natural, and that's too kind and tender by half.

column2: And I'm as good as engaged to be married to another; and another far handsomer than Jem; only I think I like Jem's face best for all that; liking's liking, and there's no help for it.
column3: And I'm as good as engaged to be married to another; and another far handsomer than Jem; only I think I like Jem's face best for all that; liking's liking, and there's no help for it.

column2: Well, when I'm Mrs. Harry Carson, may happen I can put some good fortune in Jem's way.
column3: Well, when I'm mrs Harry Carson, may happen I can put some good fortune in Jem's way.

column2: But will he thank me for it?
column3: But will he thank me for it?

column2: He's rather savage at times, that I can see, and perhaps kindness from me, when I'm another's, will only go against the grain.
column3: He's rather savage at times, that I can see, and perhaps kindness from me, when I'm another's, will only go against the grain.

column2: I'll not plague myself wi' thinking any more about him, that I won't."
column3: I'll not plague myself wi' thinking any more about him, that I won't."

column2: So she turned on her pillow, and fell asleep, and dreamt of what was often in her waking thoughts; of the day when she should ride from church in her carriage, with wedding-bells ringing, and take up her astonished father, and drive away from the old dim work-a-day court for ever, to live in a grand house, where her father should have newspapers, and pamphlets, and pipes, and meat dinners every day,--and all day long if he liked.
column3: So she turned on her pillow, and fell asleep, and dreamt of what was often in her waking thoughts; of the day when she should ride from church in her carriage, with wedding bells ringing, and take up her astonished father, and drive away from the old dim work a day court for ever, to live in a grand house, where her father should have newspapers, and pamphlets, and pipes, and meat dinners every day,--and all day long if he liked.

column2: Such thoughts mingled in her predilection for the handsome young Mr. Carson, who, unfettered by work-hours, let scarcely a day pass without contriving a meeting with the beautiful little milliner he had first seen while lounging in a shop where his sisters were making some purchases, and afterwards never rested till he had freely, though respectfully, made her acquaintance in her daily walks.
column3: Such thoughts mingled in her predilection for the handsome young mr Carson, who, unfettered by work hours, let scarcely a day pass without contriving a meeting with the beautiful little milliner he had first seen while lounging in a shop where his sisters were making some purchases, and afterwards never rested till he had freely, though respectfully, made her acquaintance in her daily walks.

column2: He was, to use his own expression to himself, quite infatuated by her, and was restless each day till the time came when he had a chance, and, of late, more than a chance of meeting her.
column3: He was, to use his own expression to himself, quite infatuated by her, and was restless each day till the time came when he had a chance, and, of late, more than a chance of meeting her.

column2: There was something of keen practical shrewdness about her, which contrasted very bewitchingly with the simple, foolish, unworldly ideas she had picked up from the romances which Miss Simmonds' young ladies were in the habit of recommending to each other.
column3: There was something of keen practical shrewdness about her, which contrasted very bewitchingly with the simple, foolish, unworldly ideas she had picked up from the romances which Miss Simmonds' young ladies were in the habit of recommending to each other.

column2: Yes! Mary was ambitious, and did not favour Mr. Carson the less because he was rich and a gentleman.
column3: Yes! Mary was ambitious, and did not favour mr Carson the less because he was rich and a gentleman.

column2: The old leaven, infused years ago by her aunt Esther, fermented in her little bosom, and perhaps all the more, for her father's aversion to the rich and the gentle. Such is the contrariness of the human heart, from Eve downwards, that we all, in our old-Adam state, fancy things forbidden sweetest.
column3: The old leaven, infused years ago by her aunt esther, fermented in her little bosom, and perhaps all the more, for her father's aversion to the rich and the gentle. Such is the contrariness of the human heart, from Eve downwards, that we all, in our old Adam state, fancy things forbidden sweetest.

column2: So Mary dwelt upon and enjoyed the idea of some day becoming a lady, and doing all the elegant nothings appertaining to ladyhood.
column3: So Mary dwelt upon and enjoyed the idea of some day becoming a lady, and doing all the elegant nothings appertaining to ladyhood.

column2: It was a comfort to her, when scolded by Miss Simmonds, to think of the day when she would drive up to the door in her own carriage, to order her gowns from the hasty tempered yet kind dressmaker.
column3: It was a comfort to her, when scolded by Miss Simmonds, to think of the day when she would drive up to the door in her own carriage, to order her gowns from the hasty tempered yet kind dressmaker.

column2: It was a pleasure to her to hear the general admiration of the two elder Miss Carsons, acknowledged beauties in ball-room and street, on horseback and on foot, and to think of the time when she should ride and walk with them in loving sisterhood.
column3: It was a pleasure to her to hear the general admiration of the two elder Miss Carsons, acknowledged beauties in ball room and street, on horseback and on foot, and to think of the time when she should ride and walk with them in loving sisterhood.

column2: But the best of her plans, the holiest, that which in some measure redeemed the vanity of the rest, were those relating to her father; her dear father, now oppressed with care, and always a disheartened, gloomy person.
column3: But the best of her plans, the holiest, that which in some measure redeemed the vanity of the rest, were those relating to her father; her dear father, now oppressed with care, and always a disheartened, gloomy person.

column2: How she would surround him with every comfort she could devise (of course, he was to live with them), till he should acknowledge riches to be very pleasant things, and bless his lady-daughter!
column3: How she would surround him with every comfort she could devise (of course, he was to live with them), till he should acknowledge riches to be very pleasant things, and bless his lady daughter!

column2: Every one who had shown her kindness in her low estate should then be repaid a hundred-fold.
column3: Every one who had shown her kindness in her low estate should then be repaid a hundred fold.

column2: Such were the castles in air, the Alnaschar-visions in which Mary indulged, and which she was doomed in after days to expiate with many tears.
column3: Such were the castles in air, the Alnaschar visions in which Mary indulged, and which she was doomed in after days to expiate with many tears.

column2: Meanwhile, her words--or, even more, her tones--would maintain their hold on Jem Wilson's memory.
column3: Meanwhile, her words-or, even more, her tones-would maintain their hold on Jem Wilson's memory.

column2: A thrill would yet come over him when he remembered how her hand had rested on his arm.
column3: A thrill would yet come over him when he remembered how her hand had rested on his arm.

column2: The thought of her mingled with all his grief, and it was profound, for the loss of his brothers.
column3: The thought of her mingled with all his grief, and it was profound, for the loss of his brothers.
